CTR Preliminary Application

 

pal Investigator: Scott A. Ness

 

 

 

 

 

August 12, 1993
BIOGRAPHICAL SKETCH
AWE POSTION TITLE
Scott A. Ness Assistant Professor
EDUCATION (Begin with baccalaureate or othr ita professional education, such as nursing, ad inlude postdoctoral
training.)
| YEAR
INSTITUTION AND LOCATION pecree | oonrenacD FIELD OF STUDY
University of California, San Diego; La Jolla, CA BA. 1980 Biology
University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) Ph.D. 1985 Biochemistry
Postdoctoral Fellowship, European Molecular Biology|
Laboratory, Heidelberg, Germany Oncogenes

 

 

Professional Experience:

1988-1991 Staff Scientist, Differentiation Programme, European Molecular Biology Laboratory,
Heidelberg, Germany (Attached to Thomas Graf's laboratory).

1991-Present Assistant Professor, Department of Biochemistry, Molecular Biology and Cell
Biology, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL.

Honors and Awards:
1979 Chancellor's Undergraduate Research Grant, Univ. of California, San Diego

1979-1980 Undergraduate Teaching Assistant (Genetics), Univ. of California, San Diego
1981-1984 USPHS Predoctoral Training Grant (Molecular Biology), Univ. of Calif., Los Angeles
1984 Graduate Division Research Grant, Univ. of California, Los Angeles

1986-1989 USPHS Post-doctoral Fellowship (for study abroad), #5 F32 CA08076-01-03

 

Bibliography: (Total of 13 Reviewed Papers)

1, SA. Ness and R.L. Weiss. "Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetases From Neurospora crassa.
Immunological Relatedness of the Enzymes From Neurospora, Bacteria, Yeast and
Mammals." (1985) J. Biol. Chem, 260, 14355-14362.

2. A. Wandinger-Ness, S.A. Ness and R-L. Weiss. "Simultaneous Purification of Three
Mitochondrial Enzymes; Acetyglutamate Kinase, Actylutamyl-phosphate Reductase and
Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase From Neurospora crass." (1986) . Biol. Chem. 261,
4820-4827.

3. S.A. Ness and R.L. Weiss.  "Carboxyl-Terminal Sequences Influence the Import of
Minchondeal rotein Precursors in vive." (1987) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA 84, 6692-
6696.

 

@ 4 SA. Ness, H. Beug and 7. Graf. *v-myb Dominance over v-myc in Doubly Transformed

Chick Myelomonocytic Cells.” (1987) Cell 51, 41-50.

Page 4

summary: CTR Preliminary Application: Scott A. Ness, Ph.D. Scott Ness is Assistant Professor of Biochemistry, Molecular Biology and Cell Biology at Northwestern University, Evanston, IL. He is the author of 13 Reviewed Papers and has worked in Germany and the U.S.
